question: What must a rock be formed from to be classified as igneous?

content.source_1: Igneous rocks form when molten rock (magma underground or lava at the surface) cools and solidifies, crystallizing into new rock.
content.source_2: In geology, rocks are classified chiefly by the process by which they formed: igneous, sedimentary, or metamorphic.
content.source_3: A shared hallmark of all igneous rocks is origin from a melt; differences in cooling rate produce textures ranging from glassy to coarse-crystalline.
content.source_4: Pyroclastic igneous rocks such as tuff form when volcanic ash and rock fragments are deposited and then compacted and cemented into a solid rock; tuff is categorized as an igneous rock.
content.source_5: Compaction and cementation (lithification) are the processes that convert loose sediments or volcanic ash into coherent rock layers.
content.source_6: Extensive volcanic provinces often include thick, laterally continuous beds of tuff, and field identification of igneous units there commonly relies on recognizing these lithified ash layers.
